Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the step-parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You see a coworker about to walk under a suspended load, and you must shout to warn them instantly.
Story: I was standing in the corner of the small grocery store, my stepson’s hand in mine, when I saw the crumpled candy wrapper peeking from his pocket. My heart sank. I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to be the parent he needed, even if it meant being the bad guy for a moment. I opened my mouth to speak, to gently but firmly guide him through this mistake, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a call from the site—urgent. I answered, and through the static, I heard the foreman’s frantic voice: “Someone’s about to walk under the crane!” My mind split in two. On one side, my stepson’s wide, guilty eyes, waiting for my judgment. On the other, the image of my coworker, oblivious to the danger above. Both needed me, right now. My chest tightened as I tried to weigh the demands—be the responsible parent, or the vigilant laborer. I could feel the seconds slipping away, each one demanding a different part of me, and I didn’t know which voice to answer first.
